column3: Clue
A research method involving a moderated discussion with a small group of participants, used to explore attitudes and perceptions.
A one-on-one conversation where a researcher asks open-ended questions to explore a topic in great detail with a single participant.
The study of people in their own environment through the use of methods such as participant observation and face-to-face interviewing.
A qualitative approach where the researcher develops a theory 'grounded' in the data collected from the field.
An in-depth investigation of a single individual, group, or event.
A set of questions or topics to be covered during a qualitative interview or focus group.
column4: What is an Interview Guide (or Discussion Guide)?

column3: A follow-up question used by an interviewer to encourage a participant to elaborate on a response.
A data collection method where the researcher becomes part of the community they are studying to gain a deeper understanding.
The detailed notes taken by a researcher describing what they have seen, heard, and experienced during an observational study.
A technique where participants are asked to create a collage or collection of images to represent their feelings about a topic.
The process of reading through qualitative data to identify and label recurring ideas, themes, or patterns.
The point in data collection when no new insights or themes are emerging from the data.
A method for systematically analyzing the content of communications, such as text, images, or videos.
The process of organizing and interpreting qualitative data to identify themes and patterns.
A detailed, rich description of a person, place, or event in a qualitative research report.
A non-probability technique where participants are selected based on the researcher's judgment of who would be most informative.
column4: What is Purposive Sampling (or Judgmental Sampling)?

column3: A technique where existing study subjects recruit future subjects from among their acquaintances.
A non-probability technique where researchers select participants who are easily accessible.
In qualitative research, this refers to the number of participants or data sources, which is typically much smaller than in quantitative studies.
A type of purposive sampling where researchers select cases that are particularly unusual or different to learn from their extremity.
The practice of keeping participants' identities and personal information private and not disclosing it to others.
The ethical requirement to obtain voluntary agreement from participants after they have been fully informed about the research.
The process of concealing the identity of participants so that even the researcher cannot link the data to a specific individual.
The ethical principle that emphasizes minimizing harm and maximizing benefits for research participants.
A review committee established to protect the rights and welfare of human research subjects.
column4: What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
